G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and related provisions governing the jurisdiction of the District Court Department, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and related venue statutes because the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the Defendant transacts business and maintains the Premises within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: As a paying customer and invitee, Plaintiff was on the Premises for a purpose directly connected with Defendant’s business, and Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to use reasonable care to keep the Premises in a reasonably safe condition. See, e.g., Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (abolishing common-law distinctions and recognizing duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and adopting a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to all lawful visitors. The quoted text is only a concurrence, but the majority opinion expressly recognizes that lawful entrants, including paying business customers, are owed a duty of reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe. Thus the case is accurately cited for the proposition that a business owner owes such a duty to a paying invitee.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "We hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. We therefore abolish the distinction between licensees and invitees as it relates to the duty owed by an occupier of land in the management of his property. Henceforth the duty of care owed by the occupier of land will be the same to all lawful visitors."

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Alternatively, the visible cart tracks through the spilled milk and the presence of the employee nearby support a finding of constructive notice, in that the condition existed for a sufficient period that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care and proper inspections, should have discovered and remedied or warned of it. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition relies on traditional constructive notice concepts (e.g., cart tracks, nearby employee showing the spill existed long enough to be discovered), but Sheehan expressly moves away from requiring proof of actual or constructive notice of the specific hazard. The court adopts the mode of operation approach, under which notice is satisfied by showing that an unsafe condition was reasonably foreseeable from the store’s self-service operation, not by evidence such as tracks or employee proximity. Thus, Sheehan does not support using those kinds of facts to prove constructive notice in the traditional sense cited in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Adopting this new approach to premises liability does not make the owner of a self-service or modem grocery store an insurer against all accidents, but instead removes the burden on the victim of a slip and fall to prove that the owner or the owner’s employees had actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition or to prove the exact failure that caused the accident… Under the mode of operation approach, a ‘plaintiff’s proof of a particular mode-of-operation simply substitutes for the traditional elements of a prima facie case — the existence of a dangerous condition and notice of a dangerous condition.’”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant’s employees were acting within the course and scope of their employment and/or agency with Defendant, making Defendant vicariously liable under the doctrine of respondeat superior. See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317 (2002).
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion does hold that an employer may be vicariously liable for the negligence of its physician-employee under respondeat superior without needing to control specific medical decisions, but it does not find that the physician was in fact acting within the scope of employment at the relevant time. The court instead vacates summary judgment because there is a factual dispute over whether the doctor was acting for BMA or another group when treating the patient. Thus, the case supports the general legal standard for respondeat superior, not the specific factual assertion that employees were acting within the scope of employment here.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. … There remains one point that requires further comment. Dr. Schlitzer was the employee of BMA on the date of the alleged negligent treatment, but the record is ambiguous as to whether he was acting as BMA’s employee at the time he treated the plaintiff.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Any comparative negligence on the part of Plaintiff, which is expressly denied, is less than any negligence attributable to Defendant, and in any event is governed by the comparative negligence principles set forth in G.L. c. 231, § 85 and cases applying it, including Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).proposition: Any comparative negligence on the part of Plaintiff, which is expressly denied, is less than any negligence attributable to Defendant, and in any event is governed by the comparative negligence principles set forth in G.L. c. 231, § 85 and cases applying it, including Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: The employee’s admission that he had noticed the spill “a few minutes ago” before Plaintiff fell demonstrates actual knowledge of the dangerous condition and a failure to take reasonable, timely action. See, e.g., Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (liability where defendant has actual notice and fails to act reasonably).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss liability based on actual knowledge versus constructive notice, but Oliveri is a constructive-notice case and ultimately holds there was *insufficient* evidence of negligence; it does not involve an employee admitting contemporaneous awareness of a spill or failing to act after such actual notice. The cited pages generally restate the duty of a possessor of business premises and survey when negligence can be inferred from the condition of a foreign substance, but they do not stand as an example of liability where the defendant had actual notice and then failed to take reasonable, timely action. Using Oliveri as affirmative authority for liability on actual notice therefore overstates and mischaracterizes the decision.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance. … In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present … for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Even if Defendant lacked actual knowledge, the visible cart tracks and the location of the spill in a busy dairy aisle show that the condition existed long enough that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care and inspection procedures, should have discovered and corrected it, and thus had constructive notice. See Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (constructive notice from condition’s duration); Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The case discusses constructive notice and the need to show that a dangerous condition existed long enough to be discovered through reasonable care, but it holds that the plaintiff failed to make that showing. The court finds no evidence that the spill’s appearance or circumstances (including the nearby cashier) demonstrated sufficient duration or opportunity for discovery, and it reverses the verdict. Thus, Deagle is authority limiting constructive notice in such spill cases, not supporting the proposition that visible tracks and aisle location established constructive notice here.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… The record discloses no description of the appearance of the oil which would in any way suggest that it had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time to have been discovered… On the evidence here we think that the negligence of the defendant is left to conjecture.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Even if Defendant lacked actual knowledge, the visible cart tracks and the location of the spill in a busy dairy aisle show that the condition existed long enough that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care and inspection procedures, should have discovered and corrected it, and thus had constructive notice. See Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (constructive notice from condition’s duration); Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955).
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly bases liability on constructive notice inferred from the condition and location of the melted ice cream, despite no evidence of actual knowledge. It emphasizes that from the dirty, melted, trampled state of the ice cream and its placement at the busy exit—visible to nearby cashiers—the jury could infer it had been present long enough that, in the exercise of reasonable care, the defendant should have discovered and removed it. This directly supports the proposition that visible condition and location can show sufficient duration to establish constructive notice without actual knowledge.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance. … The record shows that the ice cream must have come upon the floor within the period of thirty minutes… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in after the accident as described by the plaintiff. … [T]he jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions, as described above, were a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002) (defining proximate cause and foreseeability).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case does discuss and define proximate cause and foreseeability in negligence, but it holds that the defendant’s conduct was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries as a matter of law because intervening events were a superseding cause. Thus, Kent is authority limiting proximate cause in analogous circumstances, not supporting a generic assertion that a defendant’s acts and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries. Using it to affirmatively support causation is therefore inaccurate or at least misleading.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events … have otherwise extinguished the element of proximate cause and become a superseding cause of the harm.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The type of accident that occurred—a customer slipping on spilled liquid in a supermarket aisle—is a foreseeable consequence of failing to timely clean up or warn of such spills, and is within the scope of the risk created by Defendant’s negligence. See Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996).
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence states that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That is the opposite of the proposition claimed, which asserts that such an accident is a foreseeable consequence within the scope of the risk. Thus, Poskus is being mis-cited for this proposition; it actually rejects foreseeability on its facts rather than affirming it.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff has endured and continues to endure physical pain and discomfort, mental and emotional distress, inconvenience, and a loss of enjoyment of life as a result of the fall and injuries. See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in actions for personal injuries).

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all past and future special damages (including medical expenses and lost earnings) and general damages (including pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life) proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence. See doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (1975) (damages principles); Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198 (1999).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses damages only in the narrow context of whether a $440,000 verdict for the injured plaintiff was excessive and lists the specific elements the trial judge could consider. It does not articulate any general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all past and future special and general damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence, nor does it set out a comprehensive damages standard. The case is therefore not good authority for the broad damages proposition cited, even though its excessiveness review is consistent with general tort damages principles.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital...; her disfigurement...; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all past and future special damages (including medical expenses and lost earnings) and general damages (including pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life) proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence. See doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (1975) (damages principles); Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198 (1999).
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198.support_reasoning: This opinion focuses on liability, evidentiary issues, wrongful death comparative negligence, indemnity, and nunc pro tunc judgment, not on defining the scope or elements of recoverable tort damages. While the jury’s award included categories like pain and suffering, wrongful death, and lost future earnings, the court does not articulate a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all past and future special and general damages proximately caused by negligence. Thus Santos is not authority for the broad damages proposition stated.
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded $12.8 million in compensatory damages for the wrongful deaths of the wife and children, the conscious pain and suffering of the wife, the wife’s lost future earnings, and the plaintiff’s personal injuries. The jury also awarded $15,705 in punitive damages.”

Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.proposition: To the extent Defendant alleges negligence on the part of Plaintiff, such negligence is denied. However, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85, any such alleged negligence on Plaintiff’s part, if found by the trier of fact, does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the total negligence of the Defendant, and any damages shall be diminished in proportion to any negligence attributable to Plaintiff. See Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50 (1988).
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses and applies Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, to negligence claims. It states that in negligence actions the plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the total negligence of the defendants, and that otherwise recovery is only diminished proportionally. That is exactly the legal rule summarized in the proposition, so the citation is accurate and directly on point.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as allowed by G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and the applicable Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
